awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Developing technology for social-emotional learning for young children
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is making social and emotional learning (SEL) accessible and fun for children worldwide.  Social and emotional learning starts at home and caregivers play a significant role in SEL. Social and emotional development at preschool and kindergarten ages is particularly important because even though social and emotional skills are progressive, developing these skills at these early ages helps children get ready for school, and perform better academically and socially. While some children have various play and collaboration opportunities at their home and preschools, some do not. The project will not only help children develop SEL skills, but also help parents and teachers learn more about social and emotional development.

This I-Corps project includes a new learning technology for social-emotional learning.  It will enable children to transform abstract emotions into tangible objects they can learn from and share. The technology uses artificial intelligence to recognize the objects created by the children and then creates digital content that strengthens social-emotional intelligence. This technology can be used to strengthen child engagement with existing learning tools. The resulting data will benefit social-emotional learning research and will help children develop skills that are crucial for their current and future wellbeing. The technology approaches the world of social and emotional learning through a constructionist approach where learners will be able to interact with abstract thoughts and emotions. Most existing technologies in this space do not require user engagement and use passive learning techniques. With this technology, children are empowered and excited to actively participate and engage, while parents can discover insights and trends into their children's day to day experiences and emotional expression habits.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our NSF I-Corps project aimed to explore the potential for integrating educational technology and tangible play to enhance social-emotional learning (SEL) outcomes for young children. We set out to understand the market needs around SEL education and how technology could address them. Through an iterative process of hypothesis testing and customer discovery, we sought to validate our business model canvas and identify the most promising opportunities for impact.

 
We took an interdisciplinary approach combining expertise in developmental psychology, learning sciences, human-computer interaction, and AI. We conducted over 240 interviews with diverse stakeholders including educators, parents, therapists, researchers, and industry practitioners. These conversations allowed us to test and refine our assumptions about customer segments, value propositions, and market demand.

 
Our key findings included a widespread parental desire for educational screen time paired with hands-on learning extensions. Parents expressed a need for tools to curate high-quality, age-appropriate content aligned with their child's developmental needs. Parents of children with special needs voiced a strong interest in accessible, customized SEL resources that address the unique social-emotional challenges faced by their children. They emphasized the importance of adaptability, visual supports, and clear guidance to make SEL content usable and impactful.
 

In our interviews, media and toy companies showed enthusiasm for enhancing engagement and educational impact, recognizing the growing demand for purposeful experiences. However, they grappled with the rise of generative AI and its potential to both enable innovative personalized content and disrupt traditional creation models. Our interviews surfaced a need for effective content curation and supplementary materials to differentiate offerings and facilitate learning transfer while navigating the challenges and opportunities posed by generative AI.

 
Based on these insights, we iterated on our business model canvas, focusing our value proposition on empowering parents to curate personalized SEL content and activities. We also published a peer-reviewed paper at the Interaction Design & Children conference on our novel solution blending digital and tangible SEL experiences [1]. While this early-stage prototype showed promise, we identified the need for further R&D and user testing to achieve product-market fit. A key realization was the potential to leverage existing media content for more affordable and impactful solutions that are curated using AI.

 
Intellectual Merit:

 Our project made substantial contributions to advancing interdisciplinary knowledge at the intersection of learning sciences, HCI, and AI. Through extensive customer discovery, we generated valuable qualitative insights into the needs, pain points, and opportunities in the early childhood SEL ecosystem. Furthermore, our publication on an AI-powered tangible/digital SEL system represents a novel technological contribution. By demonstrating the feasibility and promise of bridging tangible and digital learning, our work expands the design space for educational technologies and highlights new avenues for personalized, multimodal learning interventions.


Broader Impacts:

 Our work has significant potential to positively impact early childhood education and development, especially for underserved populations. By equipping parents with tools to curate and reinforce SEL skills, we can foster more effective learning environments and amplify our impact. Widespread access to affordable, high-quality SEL resources benefits society by equipping the next generation with vital competencies linked to positive life outcomes [2-4]. As one parent of a child with special needs powerfully stated, "I don't know whether you can change the world, but you can change the world of my kid," underscoring the transformative potential of accessible, effective SEL tools for children and families who often lack adequate support.

 

In summary, our key outcomes include:

  1. Extensive market insights validating needs and opportunities for technological innovation in early childhood SEL.
  2. Peer-reviewed publication on an AI-driven tangible/digital SEL system.
  3. Refined business model canvas focused on empowering parents as SEL educators.
  4. Identification of areas for continued R&D to achieve real-world impact, especially for underserved learners.

 

 

 

 


Exemplifying the NSF I-Corps spirit, this work advanced fundamental knowledge while laying the groundwork for research-driven innovations to support the lifelong flourishing of all children. Building on this exploratory phase, we are well-positioned to develop robust, affordable, and inclusive SEL solutions for children, families, and educators. We are grateful for the NSF I-Corps support that has been instrumental in our progress.


References

 
[1] Cerit, M., Vainer, D., & Haber, N. (2023, June). Tingets 2.0: Computer Vision-Powered Interactive Social and Emotional Learning Tool. In Proceedings of the 22nd International Conference on Interaction Design and Children. https://doi.org/10.1145/3594781.3594797
[2] Schweinhart, L. J. (2003). Benefits, Costs, and Explanation of the High/Scope Perry Preschool Program.[3] Shala, M. (2013). The impact of preschool social-emotional development on academic success of elementary school students. Psychology, 4(11), 787.
[4] Agenda, I. (2016, March). New vision for education: Fostering social and emotional learning through technology. In World Economic Forum, March (Vol. 36).

 


Last Modified: 03/21/2024
Modified by: Nicholas J Haber
